Study: Rural and Remote Cardiology During the COVID-19 Pandemic: Cardiac Society of Australia and New Zealand (CSANZ) Consensus Statement #
Study Population: Movement of medical staff between health services may carry a risk of COVID-19
Sample Text: CSANZ guidelines recommend full PPE for cardiac catheterisation procedures in STEMI, and in patients with suspected and confirmed COVID-19.
Matches: In an older rural population, at higher risk of poor outcomes due to COVID-19, support will be necessary.

Study: COVID-19 Pandemic: Impact on Psychiatric Care in the United States, a Review
Study Population: Pubmed was searched using the terms "COVID-19" AND "psychiatric care".
Sample Text: In New Jersey state psychiatric hospitals, six patients died from COVID-19 as of March 19th, 2020.
Matches: Second, patients with SUDs are more likely to be in a lower socioeconomic status, leading to poor access to care.

Study: Bereavement support on the frontline of COVID-19: Recommendations for hospital clinicians
Journal: Journal of Pain and Symptom Management
Study Population: Most deaths from COVID-19 currently occur in hospital.
Sample Text: COVID-19 brings with it new challenges and difficulties in caring for patients and their loved ones, and supporting staff.
Matches: Poor bereavement outcomes are associated with being a female relative, a spouse, older age, trauma, and lower educational attainment, socioeconomic status and social support .

Study: Socially distanced school-based nutrition program feeding under COVID 19 in the rural Niger Delta
Study Population: In order to combat the spread of COVID 19, the Rivers State Government ordered all schools to close on March 23, 2020.
Sample Text: We based our nutrition program selection criteria on the findings of our pre project questionnaire, findings of medical and physical examinations including laboratory investigations and dietary history of 100 pupils.
Matches: Malnutrition is an unbearable burden not only on the health system, but for the entire socio-economic and cultural status of the society.

Journal: Research in Social and Administrative Pharmacy
Study Population: 4, 5 Patients are also more likely to experience severe illness with COVID-19 if they have diabetes, COPD, or cardiovascular disease at baseline, or if they smoke or are male.
Sample Text: 4, 5 Patients are also more likely to experience severe illness with COVID-19 if they have diabetes, COPD, or cardiovascular disease at baseline, or if they smoke or are male.

Study Population: Other symptoms of vomiting and diarrhea in children have been reported (American Academy of Pediatrics, 2020; U.S. Centers for Disease Control, 2020).
Sample Text: At that time, nurses' practices were governed by Florence Nightingale's precepts of good hygiene, nutrition, fresh air, and rest.

Study Population: We acknowledge the support of the Open Access Publication Funds of the University of Goettingen.
Sample Text: Moreover, handling patients in nature can have a positive influence on the quality of life of patients compared to routine therapeutic settings in hospitals .

Study: COVID-19 outbreak at a large homeless shelter in Boston: Implications for universal testing
Challenge: Evolving Cluster of COVID Cases in a Homeless Shelter in Boston
Solution: Universal PCR testing, rather than a symptom triggered approach, may be a better strategy for identifying and mitigating COVID-19 among people experiencing homelessness

Study: Multidisciplinary research priorities for the COVID-19 pandemic: a call for action for mental health science
Challenge: Impact on Mental Health Services from the Pandemic
Solution: Multidisciplinary mental health science research must be central to the international response to the COVID-19 pandemic, given the potential effects on individual and population mental health, and its potential effect on the brain function of some of those affected by the disease.

Study: U.S. county-level characteristics to inform equitable COVID-19 response
Challenge: Not all Americans are equally at risk of infection, severe disease, or mortality
Solution: Both the federal and state governments will benefit from recognizing high intra-state, inter-county variation in population risks and response capacity.

Study: Epidemiology of COVID-19 among people experiencing homelessness: Early evidence from Boston
Journal: Annals of Family Medicine, COVID-19 Collection
Challenge: People experiencing homelessness in Boston are at high risk for coronavirus disease
Solution: Municipalities with sizable homeless populations should prepare urgently for the possibility of a surge in COVID-19 among people experiencing homelessness

Study: The Challenge of Preventing COVID-19 Spread in Correctional Facilities
Challenge: Social distancing to minimize transmission of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is virtually impossible in correctional
Solution: Releasing incarceated Individuals and increase thermoteters and hand sanitizer in prisons

Study: Mitigating and learning from the impact of COVID-19 infection on addictive disorders
Challenge: The novel coronavirus pandemic of 2020 presents vast challenges to humanity, and particularly to vulnerable populations including people with addictive disorders
Solution: There is an urgent need to co-ordinate efforts nationally and internationally to mitigate these problems and to find innovative ways of continuing to provide clinical and public health services to help people with addictive disorders.

Study: Addressing the COVID-19 Pandemic in Populations With Serious Mental Illness
Journal: Journal of American Medical Association Psychiatry
Challenge: Disasters disproportionately affect poor and vulnerable populations, and patients with serious mental illness may be among the hardest hit
Solution: Expand and Strengthen Mental Health Services

Study: Flattening the Curve for Incarcerated Populations — Covid-19 in Jails and Prisons
Challenge: People entering jails are among the most vulnerable in our society, and during incarceration, that vulnerability is exacerbated by restricted movement, confined spaces, and limited medical care.
Solution: We believe in decarcerating, focusing on those who are least likely to commit additional crimes, but also on the elderly and infirm. Also urging police and courts to immediately suspend arresting and sentencing people, as much as possible, for low-level crimes and misdemeanors.

Study: Fighting covid-19 outbreaks in prisons
Challenge: Poor prison healthcare has been reported by Armstrong
Solution: Health education for inmates and prison staff must be intensified, and better treatment and prevention measures require increased funding. More non-custodial sentences would decongest prisons, reducing the potential for the outbreaks seen in China.

Study: Addressing the Threat of COVID-19-Related Housing Instability and Displacement in Delaware
Journal: Center for Community Research and Service & Institute for Public Administration Joseph R. Biden, Jr. School of Policy and Public Administration University of Delaware
Challenge: The economic toll from COVID-19 and the responses to this pandemic will increase housing instability and housing displacement in Delaware
Solution: Income assistance represents the initial bulwark against housing instability

Study: Estimated Emergency and Observational/ Quarantine Capacity Need for the US Homeless Population Related to COVID-19 Exposure by County; Projected Hospitalizations, Intensive Care Units and Mortality
Challenge: The rapid progression of the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 pandemic has raised concerns about the potential impact of coronavirus disease on the homeless population
Solution: The current crisis is likely to cause upwards of 21,000 hospitalizations and 3,400 deaths in the homeless population. There is a need to create adequate and humane accommodations for people living unsheltered during the pandemic

Study: Responding to Covid‐19: How to Navigate a Public Health Emergency Legally and Ethically
Challenge: When the health system becomes stretched beyond capacity, how can we ethically allocate scarce health goods and services? How can we ensure that marginalized populations can access the care they need?
Solution: Decisions about who is tested or who receives treatment must center on prevention of SARS‐CoV‐2 transmission (public health), protection of individuals at highest risk, meeting societal needs, and promoting social justice

Study: Efforts escalate to protect homeless people from COVID-19 in UK
Challenge: Homeless people often have multiple chronic conditions and live together in shared and cramped accommodation, or on the streets; they are, therefore, vulnerable to high rates of infection and mortality without urgent intervention
Solution: UK government that rough sleepers, or those at risk of rough sleeping, will be supported by £3·2 million of initial emergency funding if they need to self-isolate to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

Study: Covid-19: control measures must be equitable and inclusive
Challenge: Failure to respect the needs of vulnerable groups will seriously undermine response efforts
Solution: Fair and equitable sharing of resources as well as free tests are needed

Study: Securing the Safety Net and Protecting Public Health During a Pandemic: Medicaid’s Response to COVID-19
Challenge: COVID-19 has exposed gaps in the social safety net in the US. Medicaid, which covers 71 million individuals, has an important responsibility in addressing these gaps
Solution: Medicaid programs can fund unexpected health care services that other insurance plans may exclude and are thus well-positioned to ensure that vulnerable patients have access to important health care services, and that hospitals and other health care organizations and clinicians are reimbursed for providing that care.

Study: Prisons and custodial settings are part of a comprehensive response to COVID-19
Challenge: Prisons are epicentres for infectious diseases because of the higher background prevalence of infection, the higher levels of risk factors for infection, the unavoidable close contact in often overcrowded, poorly ventilated, and unsanitary facilities, and the poor access to healthcare services relative to that in community settings
Solution: In order for Prisons to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, prison systems need to joint plan with public health officials, limit importation and exportation of cases, increase personal protective measures, and share information with public health officials.

Study: The Coronavirus Could Hit People Experiencing Homelessness Hard
Challenge: But amid all the planning, and a growing sense of panic, the impact of the spread of COVID-19 among homeless people is not being widely discussed
Solution: Prudent action to contain the virus that targets this population [homeless] makes sense, given the risk that this population poses for the spread of the virus and the impact on the health care system.

Study: COVID-19: a potential public health problem for homeless populations
Challenge: It is probable that coronavirus disease (COVID-19) will be transmitted to people experiencing homelessness
Solution: Testing kits and training on how to recognise COVID-19 should be widely disseminated to homeless service providers and deployed in shelters, encampments, and street outreach. Alternative spaces might be needed to quarantine and treat people experiencing homelessness.
